pandae667 wrote:
>
> Thanks alot St.Ack,
>
> I think I took all your comments into consideration and updated my
> contribution accordingly.
>





Looks great.  Committed.  I duplicated your class comment in release 
notes as it describes well the difference between JerichoExtractorHTML 
and ExtractorHTML, its advantages, as well as its downsides.

Thanks for the contrib. Olaf,
St.Ack




> Regards
> Olaf
> >
> > Excellent. I've made a couple of comments over in the issue. Take
> a look.
> > St.Ack
> >
> >
> > pandae667 wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi everyone @IA,
> > >
> > > I finally found the time to commit my JerichoHTMLExtractor to the
> > > SourceForge feature request section (id: 1573708). If anyone considers
> > > it useful, finds any bugs or any major design-shortcomings feel free
> > > to report.
> > > It basically performs all the tasks that ExtractorHTML does - plus
> > > filling out FORMs default values. The form handling part might still
> > > not be perfect but seems to work just fine in my environment.
> > >
> > > Regards
> > > Olaf Freyer
> > >
> > > > I also started work on a custom extractor based on HTMLExtractor.
> > > > My primary goal is to be able to fill out FORMs with default values.
> > > > I decided to not take the "regular expression"-way as the
> > > > HTMLExtractor currently does, but base my work on jerichoHTML parser
> > > > (http://jerichohtml.sourceforge.net 
> <http://jerichohtml.sourceforge.net>
> > > <http://jerichohtml.sourceforge.net 
> <http://jerichohtml.sourceforge.net>>).
> > > > The current results seem quite promising (it is just a few percent
> > > > slower than the HTMLExtractor but uses significantly less memory and
> > > > it passes all unit test that HTMLExtractor does).
> > > > If everything fares well I might be able to provide my extractor to
> > > > the cummunity next month.
> > > >
> > > > Olaf Freyer
> > > >
> > >
> > >
> >
>
>
